item.title: Thereâ€™s No Such Thing as a Free Lunch ... Or is There? Perl Developer in Houston
item.description: Hungry for a change? Itâ€™s only one click away! Our Houston-area client has several openings ranging from junior Perl programmers with 1-2 yearsâ€™ experience, all the way up to the 40-year veterans. The client is a well-known company that builds the software which hosting companies use to allow their customers to host, build, and maintain websites.

item.title: The Step-by-Step Guide to Making your Friends Green with Envy
item.description: How many times have you been at a party and had to grin and bear it while your mates brag about their cool jobs? Robertâ€™s working from Antigua for the week, and Susanâ€™s taking yet another vacationâ€”how many days off can one woman have? Never fearâ€”weâ€™ve got the Step-by-Step Guide to Making your Friends Green with Envy.

item.title: Wanted: Junior Perl Developer Ready to Move Up from the Bunny Hill
item.description: The client helps charities fund raise online and manages online payment systems for landlords, so youâ€™ll have the satisfaction of knowing youâ€™re contributing to the greater good. And if thatâ€™s not enough for you, did we mention the annual company ski trip AND the chance to work in the mountains near Lake Geneva for a week each year, all expenses paid? Giving back never felt so good!

item.title: Mojolicious, GraphQL, and Perl Consultant (Poland and Central Europe)
item.description: Our client is looking for a Perl consultant in their Polish or Hungarian offices. As a consultant, youâ€™ll be expected to already be comfortable with Modern Perl tooling â€“ theyâ€™ll want you to be wrangling DBIx::Class resultsets and showing your Mojolicious mastery on day one.

item.title: #432 - Good Bye Hacktoberfest !!!
item.description:
Hi there

I find Hacktoberfest very addictive. How about you? This year event just concluded. I noticed lots of noise during the month to new and regulars to join the event. People like brain d foy, even published an exclusive blog to encourage and share new ideas for the event. Not sure if there is a way to figure out how individuals or groups contributed to Open Source during the event. I am specially interested how much Perl and Raku community involved. For the first time, Team Perl Weekly Challenge, took part in the Hacktoberfest event and did a great job, imho. Together they submitted 165 Pull Requests.

Personally for me as well, it was the best year ever where I contributed 160 Pull Requests. I am sure there are plenty of others who played their part. If you did take part then please do share your experience with us. It would definitely help others to learn from your experience.

It is a nice break before the 24 Pull Requests kicks in December. Till then keep hacking.
